The default values display the reference food loss and waste fractions from different sources. Note for the supply chain, a 100% value for each stage accounts for food loss and waste in each food category.

### Toolkit1
This is a new line. Edit this elsewhere, and then insert (copy-paste) it inside the hover description or extensive description column.

label: Global Diet Compositions
description: (Able to design more diets in future)
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that maintains traditional eating habits.
extensive description:
##  Diet Composition Comparison

This table compares three dietary patterns in terms of their **caloric composition** across eight food categories:

- **Reference Diet**: Represents a baseline or current average dietary intake  
- **Flexitarian Diet**: Mostly plant-based with moderate amounts of animal products  
- **Mediterranean Diet**: Plant-forward with olive oil, grains, fruits, and modest meat and dairy  

## Diet Composition Table

| **Category**   | **Reference (%)** | **Flexitarian (%)** | **Mediterranean (%)** |
|----------------|------------------:|---------------------:|-----------------------:|
| **PasMeat**     | 1.8               | 0.4                  | 1.0                    |
| **CropMeat**    | 5.6               | 2.5                  | 6.0                    |
| **Dairy**       | 6.8               | 8.0                  | 8.0                    |
| **Eggs**        | 1.2               | 0.8                  | 2.0                    |
| **Pulses**      | 2.4               | 7.1                  | 4.0                    |
| **Grains**      | 47.9              | 30.0                 | 43.0                   |
| **VegFruits**   | 8.3               | 12.1                 | 12.0                   |
| **OtherCrops**  | 26.0              | 38.4                 | 24.0                   |

label: Start Year
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: Self Efficacy
description: If you feel confident in yourself to make dietary changes, you are also more likely to shift toward sustainable eating habits.
hover description: Self Efficacy refers to an individual's belief in their ability to successfully adopt and maintain a different diet.

label: Response Efficacy
description: If you trust that your actions have impact, you are more likely to change your behavior.
hover description: Response Efficacy reflects the belief that adopting a different diet will effectively contribute to positive environmental or health outcomes.

label: Perceived Risks
description: If you perceive greater risks from the environment, you may be more likely to adopt dietary changes.
hover description: Perceived Risks is affected by both the sensitivity towards extreme events but also its frequency.

label: Perceived Risks (No Education)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate NoEd Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Primary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Primary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Secondary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Secondary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Tertiary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Tertiary Variation

label: Social Norms
description: If sustainable eating is widely accepted among your peers you are also more likely to adopt such diets.
hover description: Social Norms refer to the influence of societal and peer expectations on an individual's diet choices.

label: Conventional Diet Compositions
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that maintains traditional eating habits.

label: by Supply Chain
hover description: Toggle between Food Category and Supply Chainâ€”only one can have an impact at a time. The default values display the reference food loss and waste fractions from different sources. Note for the supply chain, a 100% value for each stage accounts for food loss and waste in each food category.

label: Start Year
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: Primary Production
hover description: Losses through Farmers, Fishers, Ranchers, Agricultural Workers
extensive description: Losses occurring at the farm level due to unharvested crops, pest damage, extreme weather, or overproduction that leads to surplus food being discarded before it enters the supply chain.

label: Post Harvest
hover description: Losses through Warehouses, Storage Facilities, Transporters
extensive description: Losses happening after harvest but before processing or distribution, often due to inadequate storage, transportation issues, spoilage, or inefficiencies in handling and drying.

label: Processing
hover description: Losses through Food Manufacturers, Factories, Butchers, Packaging
extensive description: Losses during food manufacturing, including edible portions discarded during trimming, inefficiencies in processing, and overproduction leading to disposal before reaching consumers.

label: Distribution
hover description: Losses and Waste through  Wholesalers, Retailers, Supermarkets, Deliveries
extensive description: Wastes occurring at the wholesale, retail, and food service levels due to packaging damage, expired goods, improper handling, or rejection of products based on aesthetic standards.

label: Consumption
hover description: Wastes through Households, Consumers, Restaurants, Cafeterias
extensive description: Wastes generated at the consumer level, including uneaten leftovers, spoiled groceries, and plate waste in households, restaurants, and cafeterias

label: Pasture Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[PasMeat]
hover description: Beef, Lamb, Goat, Venison.
extensive description: Meat from animals raised on grasslands, such as beef and lamb. These meats have a higher environmental impact due to land and water use.

label: Crop Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[CropMeat]
hover description: Chicken, Pork, Turkey, Duck
extensive description: Meat from animals primarily fed on crops like soy and corn, including chicken and pork. Generally, they have a lower footprint than pasture meats.

label: Dairy
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Dairy]
hover description: Milk, Cheese, Yogurt, Butter, Cream
extensive description: Products made from milk, such as cheese, yogurt, and butter. Dairy farming contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and water usage.

label: Eggs
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Eggs]
hover description: Chicken Eggs, Duck Eggs, Quail Eggs
extensive description: A nutrient-rich food source from poultry, including chicken, duck, and quail eggs. Lower environmental impact compared to meat but still requires feed and water.

label: Pulses
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Pulses]
hover description: Lentils, Chickpeas, Black Beans, Kidney Beans, Peas
extensive description: Protein-rich plant foods like lentils, beans, and chickpeas. They improve soil health and have a low carbon footprint.

label: Grains
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Grains]
hover description: Wheat, Rice, Corn, Oats, Barley, Quinoa
extensive description: Staple crops such as wheat, rice, corn, and oats. Widely consumed and essential for global food security, but some require high water usage.

label: Vegetables and Fruits
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[VegFruits]
hover description: Carrots, Potatoes, Apples, Bananas, Tomatoes, Spinach
extensive description: A diverse group including leafy greens, root vegetables, and berries. Generally have a lower environmental impact, but factors like transport and refrigeration matter.

label: Other Crops
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[OtherCrops]
hover description: Coffee, Tea, Sugarcane, Nuts, Spices
extensive description: Includes foods like nuts, sugar, coffee, and oils (palm, soybean, canola). Some have significant land-use impacts, especially tropical crops like palm oil.
